awd_titl_txt: Connecting Eruptive Transients and Their Supernovae
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigators will study an important class of massive stars, which have bright eruptions of material from their surface.  These stars are in the last stages of their stellar life cycle, sometimes just before stellar explosions as supernovae (SNe). The investigators will use telescopes of the University of Arizona to study Luminous Blue Variable (LBV) stars. They will study the material ejected around nearby LBVs and the connection between SNe brightnesses. The material from the LBVs appears as bright rings of gas surrounding the stars.  The material is visible in observations with optical telescopes and sensitive cameras.  These observations provide the only way to measure the ejected mass and speed, as well as the typical time period between large eruptions. The investigators will study the environments of LBVs in the Milky Way and nearby galaxies.  

The investigator will mentor in CAMPARE, a program that fosters diversity in science by recruiting minorities and statistically underrepresented groups for a summer undergraduate research experience at Steward Observatory.  The investigator will continue as a Sky Ambassador, working with Tucson elementary and high-school science teachers. As part of this program, they will develop instructional materials concerning the Sun and stars, supernovae, and the origin of the elements.  There research program will also fund one Ph.D. thesis and several undergraduate researchers, providing them with experience with complex multi-wavelength observational data and time-variable phenomena. 

The investigators focus on observations to understand the stellar life cycle and explosive deaths of massive stars, since SNe dominate feedback in galaxies.  SNe enrich the interstellar medium with elements, and they can be used probe conditions in the distant universe. The use of SNe to estimate of distances to galaxies hinges upon understanding the connection between massive stars and the various types of SNe they produce. Eruptive mass loss is influential in stellar evolution, and violent eruptions preceding core collapse can lead to some of the most luminous SNe known. 

This LBV/SNe connection was initially controversial because stellar models place massive LBVs in an earlier phase, but recently a dramatic confirmation of the connection between LBV stars and SNe was observed.  In 2009 an LBV star was noted in a survey of massive stars, and then in 2012 this star became a core-collapse SNe.  LBV-like eruptions may hold critical clues about stellar instability during the final phases of nuclear burning, vital to understanding core collapse. 

During these studies, the investigators will detect a large number of extragalactic transients, and constrain the luminosity, mass-loss rates, duration, and outflow speed of the eruptions. Some of these eruptive transients will soon explode as SNe, so the observations will have tremendous value for understanding the prelude to core collapse of massive stars.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to study explosive astronomical tranients,
including supernovae and non-supernova transients, and to connect them
to the late evolution and deaths of various types of massive stars.
Sometimes these explosions mark the final death of a massive star, as
in a core-collpse supernova, and sometimes they trace a violent but
non-terminal event before the supernova, such as a stellar eruption or
a merger of two stars.  We are trying to understand the mapping
between stellar evolution for different mass stars, mass loss, binary
star evolution, circumstellar material, and explosive ends.  Evidence
indicates that massive stars lose mass in steady winds at such a low
rate that the steady winds are not as important to evolution as
previously thought.  Instead, the evolution and fate of massive stars
is strongly influenced by brief episodes of mass loss, either as
eruptive mass loss events in single stars or binary interaction events
(mass transfer, common envelopes, mergers).  These brief events happen
fast andare very rare, so they cannot be studied directly by examining
populations of nearby quiescent stars, which is why we focus on
transient events.  Explosive transient events are rare in any one
galaxy like the Milky Way, but modern sky surveys that search for new
sources in many nearby galaxies are able to find many examples.  This
NSF program did not undertake a survey to discover new transient
sources, but the aim was to use the telescope resources of the
Univerity of Arizona and other telescopes to obtain detailed followup
photometry and spectroscopy of the many transient sourcers being
discovered and reported by existing surveys.  We are also studying
circumstellar material around nearby massive stars on a case-by-case
basis, and we are investigating the environments of massive stars in
the Milky Way and nearby galaxies.

Data collected as part of this program used resources such as the
Large Binocular Telescopoe (LBT), the 6.5m MMT Observatory, the dual
6.5m Magellan telescopes at Las Campanas, the 2.3m Bok telescope on
Kitt Peak, the 1.5m Kuiper telescope on Mt. Bigelow, the Hubble Space
Telescope, and numerous other telescopes with data contributed by
collaborators.  Photometric and spectroscopic data sets were collected
for well over 100 explosive transient sources, yielding over 100
papers in refereed journals.  Many of these were papers with a
detailed analysis of an individual supernova or other transient event,
while some investigated samples of multiple objects, as well as
studies of nearby stars that have suffered historical outbursts (like
the massive star Eta Carinae) and massive variable stars in nearby
galaxies like the luminous blue variables (LBVs) in the Large
Magellanic Cloud.  Undergraduate students, graduate students, and
postdoctoral scholars were involved in the research and led many of
the papers.

Although the program involved the study of many individual events,
collectively there were recurring themes that altered our
understanding of some types of explosive transients.  The main
emphasis in this study was on supernovae that seem to suffer major
eruptive mass-loss episides shortly (i.e. years to decades) before
their final death, as well as the precursor eruptive events
themselves.  The properties of the pre-supernova mass loss are
inferred from the observable sugnatures of strong shock interaction
that occurs as the explosion blast wave sweeps through the surrounding
material.  One common finding was that from an analysis of the time
evolution of spectra, it was clear that many of these events are
highly asymmetric, with gas and dust surrounding the exploding star
commonly showing signs of disk-like or bipolar shapes, rather than
spherically symmetric.  This is very suggestive that the impulsive,
eruptive mas loss that occurs shortly beforte the SN explosion is
related to violent interactions of two stars in a binary system
(mergers, stellar collisions, mass transfer events) rather than
nuclear bursts in single stars.  The reason why this binary
interaction occurs shortly before the star's death remains uncertain,
but the interaction could be triggered by the swelling of one of the
two stars in its final burning phases.  Another major finding was that
it was common that the eruptive pre-supernova mass loss was occurring
on longer timescales than previously expected, suchs as decades or
centuries (in some cases even millenia), rather than just 1-2 years
before core collapsde.  This definitively rules out some ideas for
causes of the pre-supernova eruptive mass loss that are related to the
very final nuclear burning stages in the last 1-2 years of a massive
star's life, and instead (like the asymmetry mentioned above) strongly
points to more prolonged violent binary interaction.  Lastly, another
common result from transient sources was that during the shock
interaction between the supernova blast wave and surrounding material,
observations showed clear evidence of rapid and efficient formation of
solid dust grains in these supernova events, which can make important
contributions to the dust production budget in galaxies.  Another
effort of this program involved studies of massive stars in nearby
galaxies and their surrounding environments, some of which are
eruptive variables like LBVs.  A common result of these studies is
that the ages of their environments do not agree with the expected age
of the star based on its luminosity, suggesting that the stars have
been altered by and are products of previous binary interaction
events like binary mergers.
